Lea Jones with ‘Cricket’, a four-year-old Chihuahua-Miniature Pinscher cross, and Stacey Scott with 'Bono’, a four-year-old Chihuahua-Shih Tzu cross.
This shot was taken by Clark Mishler, whom we interviewed in issue 24 of Photography Week iPad magazine.

title: By Yana Bondareva
text:
By Yana Bondareva
“In this photo I wanted to represent fragility and pureness. I kept the aperture wide in order to give it a softer appearance. I later edited the colours in Photoshop.” – Yana Bondareva

title: Issue 24 of Photography Week is now available to download on your iPad.
text:
Issue 24 of Photography Week is now available to download on your iPad.
We talk you through the whole process of creating HDR images, speak to portrait pro Clark James Mishler Photography about his 20-year quest to capture the people of Alaska, head to British Columbia for a landscape masterclass, and explain how to bracket your shots. Plus, Nikon and Canon go head-to-head in our full-frame face-off, and we get airborne with the world’s coolest camera gadget…!

title: Cat’s Paws by Mike Jones
text:
Cat’s Paws by Mike Jones
The vivid green of the moss in the foreground is set off against the misty background, accentuating the shape of the branches and foliage and creating an air of mystery.

title: Every Wednesday we feature the very best photography that has been shared to our Facebook page. Click on the images to see these fantastic photographs in full.
text:
Every Wednesday we feature the very best photography that has been shared to our Facebook page. Click on the images to see these fantastic photographs in full.
Like us on Facebook and share your work with us for the chance to be featured here and in the magazine!

title: The Flight of the Eagle Owl by Mark Bridger
text:
The Flight of the Eagle Owl by Mark Bridger
“This is a large female eagle owl which lives at the British Wildlife Centre in Lingfield, UK. I shot the image in raw and later processed it using Aperture.” – Mark

title: Harvest by Amelia Fletcher
text:
Harvest by Amelia Fletcher
“This self-portrait was shot a while ago. It represents a time when I was getting back to the roots of why I love photography, harvesting concepts and ideas that I needed to be fulfilled.” – Amelia

title: Under the Rain by Anne Maenurm
text:
Under the Rain by Anne Maenurm
“This was taken in Val Badia, in Italy, one April evening. I used a Lee graduated ND filter and a polariser. It was rainy and grey, but evenings like this have their own special charm.”   – Anne

title: The Cascade by Brad Wagner
text:
The Cascade by Brad Wagner
“This summer I met up with fellow photographer Brendon Burton in Glacier National Park, Montana. We spent the day exploring and were constantly amazed at its beauty.” – Brad

title: Ardrossan by Peter Ribbeck
text:
Ardrossan by Peter Ribbeck
“This was taken on the night of a full moon at Ardrossan highroad in Ayrshire, Scotland.” – Peter

title: Birthday Boy by Amanda Tipton
text:
Birthday Boy by Amanda Tipton
“This picture is the first in a new tradition of birthday images for my son’s special day. To me, taking pictures is seeing with my heart before my eyes, and ‘the moment’ is always paramount.” – Amanda

title: Every Wednesday we feature the very best photography that has been shared to our Facebook page. Click on the images to see these fantastic photographs in full.
text:
Every Wednesday we feature the very best photography that has been shared to our Facebook page. Click on the images to see these fantastic photographs in full.
Like us on Facebook and share your work with us for the chance to be featured here and in the magazine!

title: Frown by Thomas Leuthard
text:
Frown by Thomas Leuthard
“I was at the Zurich main railway station on 1 January when I saw this man reading in a restaurant. I was taking the photograph from outside the window when he saw me. He tried to hide behind the newspaper but was still curious to see what was going on.” – Thomas Leuthard

title: Lane by ‘Blackstation’
text:
Lane by ‘Blackstation’
“This shot is of Anhui Hongcun Alley, which is typical of the ancient alleyways of Huizhou, in the Guangdong province of China.”

title: Petite Vue De Rocamadour by Jerome Dhainaut
text:
Petite Vue De Rocamadour by Jerome Dhainaut
“This shot was taken in July 2012 in the village of Rocamadour, France. It is an HDR photograph created from five shots taken at several different exposures during the evening.” – Jerome

title: Métier: Chien de Traineau by Renald Bourque
text:
Métier: Chien de Traineau by Renald Bourque
This fantastic portrait draws your attention fully to the striking blue eyes of the dog, which has been achieved by using a wide aperture, narrowing the focus area to the immediate foreground, and reducing the details of the background to a blur.

title: Fire, Earth & Water by Christian Lim
text:
Fire, Earth & Water by Christian Lim
“This area was ravaged by floods that permanently changed the landscape. I tried to look for elements in the frame that would present a compelling story of fire, earth and water.” – Christian

title: Llanddwyn Island by Stephen McNally
text:
Llanddwyn Island by Stephen McNally
“In this image, I used the path to lead the eye to the lighthouse. I focused on the grass a third of the way in, and used the two-stop grad to hold back the sky and keep the foreground light.” – Stephen

title: Every Wednesday we feature the very best photography that has been shared to our Facebook page. Click on the images to see these fantastic photographs in full.
text:
Every Wednesday we feature the very best photography that has been shared to our Facebook page. Click on the images to see these fantastic photographs in full.
Like us on Facebook and share your work with us for the chance to be featured here and in the magazine!

title: Poached by Siebe Warmoeskerken
text:
Poached by Siebe Warmoeskerken
“Food photography in its most simple form; two slices of toast with a curry mayonnaise in between, topped with a perfectly poached egg.” – Siebe Warmoeskerken

title: By Rachel Sketchley
text:
By Rachel Sketchley
“This is a shot of my younger sister, taken in May while on a walk. When we stumbled upon an area with thousands of dandelions, I told her to collect some and then blow them towards me.” – Rachel Sketchley

title: Wanaka, New Zealand by Karen
text:
Wanaka, New Zealand by Karen
The the soft pastels of the sky, and the solitary green tree are reflected perfectly in the lake, providing an instantly calming image aided by the stillness of the water.

title: By Tim Wallace
text:
By Tim Wallace
“I left the Royal Marines, went into media network management and got made redundant. Twice. Everyone said that I should go into photography, so in November 2006 I spent five days doing a business plan.” – Tim

title: Von by Jack Fusco
text:
Von by Jack Fusco
Jack was very lucky to be able to see and photograph the Aurora Borealis on his trip to Iceland.

title: By Tim Wallace
text:
By Tim Wallace
“People don’t really develop their own photographic style as much these days. They tend to spend a lot of time analysing and trying to reverse-engineer people’s work that they see online.” – Tim

title: Still Life With Jewel Box by Kevin Best
text:
Still Life With Jewel Box by Kevin Best
“Vanitas images like this still-life are concerned with mortality and the ultimate futility of possessions. Some items are original 17th century, others – such as the violin – were made by me.” – Kevin Best

title: Chocolate Truffle by Svetlana Karner
text:
Chocolate Truffle by Svetlana Karner
This is food photography with a feel-good factor. Svetlana has carefully considered her colour palette when setting up this shot, ensuring the image has a bright and airy look.

title: By Amos Nachoum
text:
By Amos Nachoum
This image was awarded fifth place in the Science and Nature category of the International Loupe Awards 2012.

title: Every Wednesday we feature the very best photography that has been shared to our Facebook page. Click on the images to see these fantastic photographs in full.
text:
Every Wednesday we feature the very best photography that has been shared to our Facebook page. Click on the images to see these fantastic photographs in full.
Like us on Facebook and share your work with us for the chance to be featured here and in the magazine!

title: Dark and Stormy by Mike Jones
text:
Dark and Stormy by Mike Jones
Now here’s a striking image! The storm rages right on the edge of a cloud, revealing a clear and calm sky to the left. Mike has been lucky to capture this lighting strike, which has lit up the majority of the cloud, and is very well framed in the centre of the image.

title: Pair of Rabbits by Ben Hall
text:
Pair of Rabbits by Ben Hall
“The three wildlife photographers who have inspired me the most were Jim Brandenburg, Frans Lanting and Vincent Munier. I learnt from these photographers that developing your own style is imperative, and that is what I have always strived to do.” – Ben Hall

title: This fantastic shot by Jon Wright was just one of the great images from the Loupe Awards.
text:
This fantastic shot by Jon Wright was just one of the great images from the Loupe Awards. 
You can view our other favourite shots from this competition in issue 20 of Photography Week magazine for iPad.

title: Sad Tune by Jernej Lasič
text:
Sad Tune by Jernej Lasič
We love the shallow depth of field in Jernej’s portrait of a violinist, which focuses sharply on his hand and the end of the violin, blurring his face and leaving the details of his expression to the imagination, providing the image with an element of mystery.

title: Orcia by Siebe Warmoeskerken
text:
Orcia by Siebe Warmoeskerken
“This photo was taken in the backyard of the house that I rented for my vacation in Tuscany. I happened to walk out into the fields in my pyjamas to shoot the sunrise over the valley. This is pne of the best photos I’ve taken with my Hasselblad and one of the best sunrises I’ve seen yet.” – Siebe Warmoeskerken

title: Greenfinch by Ben Hall
text:
Greenfinch by Ben Hall
“I started out with pretty modest kit. My first camera was a fully manual Yashica SLR. I had a darkroom at home where I would spend hours developing black and white film and printing with an enlarger – a far cry from today’s digital world!” – Ben Hall

title: A Question of Logic by Paolo Barzman
text:
A Question of Logic by Paolo Barzman
We love the range of emotions this photograph emits; humorous, yet at the same time rather sad. Being black and white gives the image a film noir feel, encouraging the viewer to anthropomorphize the dog in the car and creating an image full of character.

title: Isle of Skye, Scotland by Mark Hamblin
text:
Isle of Skye, Scotland by Mark Hamblin
Taken with: Canon 5D Mark II with 17-40mm f/4 at 23mmExposure: 8 secs at f/16, ISO100

title: One of Mark Hamblin’s fantastic waterscapes as featured in issue 20 of Photography Week magazine for iPad.
text:
One of Mark Hamblin’s fantastic waterscapes as featured in issue 20 of Photography Week magazine for iPad.
Download this issue here: http://bit.ly/RHzJmN

title: Issue 20 of Photography Week is now available to download!
text:
Issue 20 of Photography Week is now available to download!
We’ve got the tips you need if you’re looking to capture fantastic waterscapes. We also interview nature photographers Ben Hall and Ross Hoddinott, as well as take a look at five of the latest ultra-wide lenses, and as always, we feature more incredible photography.

title: Mountain Shadow by Scott Hotaling
text:
Mountain Shadow by Scott Hotaling
“Mount Hood, the tallest peak in Oregon, is a sharper summit than most of the surrounding Cascade volcanoes. When the sun rises, a beautiful mountain shadow is cast to the west. I captured this shadow above a lake of clouds in July.” – Scott Hotaling

title: Anna’s Hummingbird by Janine Russell
text:
Anna’s Hummingbird by Janine Russell
Anna has captured a great portrait of a hummingbird, using a wide aperture to blur the background and drawing attention to the vivid colours of the bird’s feathers.

title: Secret Base by Hideyuki Katagiri
text:
Secret Base by Hideyuki Katagiri
”I would often observe the stray cats living in Kawasaki city in Japan and wanted to capture a shot of a feral cat in its secret home.“ – Hideyuki Katagiri

title: Closer by Justyna Frackowiak
text:
Closer by Justyna Frackowiak
“Late one afternoon, I spotted a place at the back of my house full of buttercups. From the picture it looks like a huge field full of flowers, but in fact it is just a little meadow.” – Justyna Frackowiak

title: Lady Love by Mohan Duwal
text:
Lady Love by Mohan Duwal
This fantastic shot has cleverly kept the main subject – the dew-encrusted ladybird – in crisp focus, while creating a beautiful bokeh of dew drops on the cobweb. This is an image that, quite literally, makes the most of the small details.

title: Eastern Screech Owl by Barb D'Arpino
text:
Eastern Screech Owl by Barb D'Arpino
“Echo is a captive owl. The tree in which she lived was cut down, and she was the only owlet that survived. She is now used for educational purposes at Mountsberg Conservation area in Ontario, Canada.” – Barb D'Arpino

title: Sunshine and Showers by Paul Garnett
text:
Sunshine and Showers by Paul Garnett
“This was taken on an autumn day at Grasmere in the Lake District, Cumbria, UK. The combination of rain and sunshine created a fantastic rainbow. The light enhanced the autumn colours and showed them at their best.” – Paul Garnett

title: Autumn by ‘Planetmonkeys’
text:
Autumn by ‘Planetmonkeys’
This image is rather untypical of a traditional landscape. The desaturated colours, with warm tones and dark shadows provide a mysterious atmosphere to the scene.

title: Every Wednesday we feature the very best photography that has been shared to our Facebook page. Click on the images to see these fantastic photographs in full.
text:
Every Wednesday we feature the very best photography that has been shared to our Facebook page. Click on the images to see these fantastic photographs in full.
Like us on Facebook and share your work with us for the chance to be featured here and in the magazine!

title: In issue 18 we interview Jordan Matter Photography on his spectacular photo series Dancers Among Us.  Download this issue to read the interview here: http://bit.ly/RHzJmN
text:
In issue 18 we interview Jordan Matter Photography on his spectacular photo series Dancers Among Us.  Download this issue to read the interview here: http://bit.ly/RHzJmN
Subscribe and get 5 free issues!

title: Two Door Cinema Club by Kristofer Brand
text:
Two Door Cinema Club by Kristofer Brand
“I got the chance to cover the Bonnaroo music festival in Tennessee last year. I had a front row view of Two Door Cinema Club and their bassist Kevin Baird.” – Kristofer Brand

title: Teamwork by Michael Steverson
text:
Teamwork by Michael Steverson
This iconic image of a Chinese fisherman with a cormorant would be right at home in a travel book or magazine. With the light from the lamp lighting the fisherman’s face, and the bird’s head turned to the side to create a perfect profile, you are drawn right into this image, which has an almost cinematic quality owing to its high contrast and deep shadows.

title: Dominance by Csaba Tokolyi
text:
Dominance by Csaba Tokolyi
This breathtaking shot, with its high contrast and rich colours, can’t fail to capture attention. With its wings outspread and its face in perfect focus, this eagle looks all the more impressive set against the backdrop of a snowy, white background.

title: By Ahn Jun
text:
By Ahn Jun
Photographer Anh Jun has brought out a series of ‘skywalking’ images, which has become a relatively popular trend in photography worldwide.

title: Answer by May L
text:
Answer by May L
This fantastic macro shot captures the small flower in crisp focus, and has expertly kept the subject in the very centre of the image. The background colours perfectly coordinate with the colours of the petals, creating a very calming feel to this image.

title: Every Wednesday we feature the very best photography that has been shared to our Facebook page. Click on the images to see these fantastic photographs in full.
text:
Every Wednesday we feature the very best photography that has been shared to our Facebook page. Click on the images to see these fantastic photographs in full.
Like us on Facebook and share your work with us for the chance to be featured here and in the magazine!

title: Icy Swan Lake by Edwin van Nuil
text:
Icy Swan Lake by Edwin van Nuil
This fantastic shot by Edwin captures perfectly a cold and bright winter’s morning. The touch of blue in the sky and the orange of the swan’s beak stand out all the more against the white of the frost and mist, and the placement of the swans toward the bottom right of the picture balance the image out perfectly.

title: “I tend to keep nearly all of my photographs very clearly processed. Generally I start out in Lightroom and do all of my raw processing there, and then I’ll move on to Photoshop for additional enhancements.” – Nicole Yong
text:
“I tend to keep nearly all of my photographs very clearly processed. Generally I start out in Lightroom and do all of my raw processing there, and then I’ll move on to Photoshop for additional enhancements.” – Nicole Yong
Visit Nicole’s website.

title: Reindeer Girl by Aurora Demasi
text:
Reindeer Girl by Aurora Demasi
“This is a portrait of the lovely Bianca. She was posing for me on a street in the north of Rome on a cold December day.” – Aurora Demasi

title: Portraits of Strangers: Alina - Hamburg by Adde Adesokan
text:
Portraits of Strangers: Alina - Hamburg by Adde Adesokan
Adde has masterfully captured this portrait, using a shallow aperture to blur out the background and drawing your attention entirely to the subject’s face, whom he’s centred very neatly in shot.

title: Red Fox Pouncing by Tin Man Photography
text:
Red Fox Pouncing by Tin Man Photography
This fantastic shot was timed perfectly to capture the red fox seemingly hanging in the air, hovering inches above the ground. The white background ensures that the fox is the only focal point, helping its red coat stand out and making this an image with real impact.

title: Overflowing Rain by Pedro Diaz Molins
text:
Overflowing Rain by Pedro Diaz Molins
“This was taken in the Parque Natural de las Lagunas de Torrevieja y la Mata in Spain. I like the minimalist style of this picture, which was achieved using a long exposure and mono treatment.” – Pedro Diaz Molins

title: Winter Wanderer by Monica Imhof-Cadosch
text:
Winter Wanderer by Monica Imhof-Cadosch
This fantastic shot was entered into our photography challenge on Facebook. We love the crisp whites and deep blacks of this very graphic image, and the way that the light strikes the edges of the rolling hills gives it a lovely three-dimensional feel.

title: Prompter and Listener by Ali Muhammad
text:
Prompter and Listener by Ali Muhammad
“In this image, I wanted to capture the natural human desire to do what we’re told or prompted to do, often without thinking about the consequences.” – Ali Muhammad

title: A Little Snow by Mark Johnson
text:
A Little Snow by Mark Johnson
Mark’s picture uses a wide aperture to focus sharply on the snowflake in the foreground, drawing attention to its intricate pattern.

title: Calm Before the Storm by Jeff Lewis
text:
Calm Before the Storm by Jeff Lewis
“The light changed so much over the hour I spent shooting that my toughest decision was which shot to post first! This one’s actually just before sunset; what you see is strong sunset light, not true alpenglow, on the domes. I chose this time because the sky was still blue and I really liked how it complimented the blue in the ice. I do have vertical comps as well, but by now you’ve probably seen a couple verticals, so here’s a horizontal to show you both sides of the lake.” – Jeff Lewis

title: Les Souhaits by Vicky Morin
text:
Les Souhaits by Vicky Morin
We love Vicky’s child portrait as it captures perfectly the wonder and joy of this little girl as she experiences the excitement of a snowfall.

title: Farm on the Hill by Marcin Sobas
text:
Farm on the Hill by Marcin Sobas
“This photo was taken in Tuscany in spring. Contrary to appearances, it was a chilly morning, but the light was gorgeous. To this day, I have in mind the sound of sheep grazing next to us!” – Marcin Sobas.

title: George Steinmetz’ image, ‘Ethiopia’.
text:
George Steinmetz’ image, ‘Ethiopia’.
He says, “Tigrean and Afari men pry slabs of salt out of the dry section of Lake Assale, in Ethiopia. The salt will be carried by camel and donkey up the East African Rift Valley to Tigray Province, where it’ll be sold for human and animal consumption. The camels depart with around 140kg of salt each – equivalent to two full-grown men.”

title: Majestic Mayon Volcano by Glen Espinosa
text:
Majestic Mayon Volcano by Glen Espinosa
This majestic landscape cleverly puts the water in the foreground of the image, while almost hidden in the background standing tall and noble is the main focus of the picture; Mayon volcano in the Philippines. Although not initially the main focus, this iconic shape on the horizon is impossible to ignore, and draws you further into the picture.

title: Raging Black Sea by Evgeni Dinev
text:
Raging Black Sea by Evgeni Dinev
“This was taken during storm in February 2012 in town of Burgas, Bulgaria. The bridge is located on a city beach on the coast of the Black Sea. The waves were about 6 meters high and it was extremely dangerous to get closer.” – Evgeni Dinev

title: Winter Reflections by Cindy Costa
text:
Winter Reflections by Cindy Costa
“This image was taken at Yosemite National Park, just after sunrise and an overnight snow shower during the night. To capture this I used a steady tripod and later used Photomatix to combine 5 different exposures to create this HDR image.” – Cindy Costa

title: We interviewed aerial photographer George Steinmetz in issue 13 of Photography Week, who takes pictures while piloting a motorised paraglider.
text:
We interviewed aerial photographer George Steinmetz in issue 13 of Photography Week, who takes pictures while piloting a motorised paraglider.
This is a self-portrait of him taken over Shibam, Yemen. He says, “One of the biggest challenges is taking pictures and flying at the same time. You have to take your hands off the controls and you can’t really see where you’re going very well. I can steer the aircraft a little bit by learning – it’s like controlling a very light jet-ski.”

title: Lapland - Kiilopää by Christian Schweiger
text:
Lapland - Kiilopää by Christian Schweiger
A very merry Christmas from the Photography Week team!

title: Festive Robin by Jacky Parker
text:
Festive Robin by Jacky Parker
It’s difficult to get more festive than a robin with a snowy background! We love the shallow depth of field in this shot, and how the robin is leaning in line with the twig it is sitting on, giving it additional charm and character.

title: The Great Divide II by Rasmus Hartikainen
text:
The Great Divide II by Rasmus Hartikainen
This elegant portrait uses a shallow depth of field to blur out any background distractions. The pose and composition complement each other well, drawing your attention directly to the model’s eye peering out of her scarf.

title: Praha XXII by Robert Pavic
text:
Praha XXII by Robert Pavic
“This was taken one foggy October morning under the Charles Bridge in Prague. While other photographers were on the bridge waiting to capture ‘that shot’, I noticed a boat under the bridge.” – Robert Pavic

title: East Coast by Lim Theamhoe
text:
East Coast by Lim Theamhoe
Lim’s stunning seascape nearly left us speechless. Now we’ve recovered slightly from the drama of this shot, we can explain that the foreground focus of the rocks brings your eye neatly in line with the lightning bolt on the horizon. From the colours in the clouds, to the blur of the clearly choppy waves, to the lighting captured at precisely the right moment, this shot is a clear demonstration of the raw power of nature. We love it.

title: A Winter Wonderland by Jessica Trinh
text:
A Winter Wonderland by Jessica Trinh
Jessica’s charming portrait of a dog in snowfall is full of personality and fun. She has cleverly got the dog to look up, giving the impression that the dog is full of wonder and excitement for the falling snow.

title: Horseshoe Bend by Andy Kennelley
text:
Horseshoe Bend by Andy Kennelley
This light trail photograph pulls your attention to the soft, curved shape of the mountain road in Moorpark, California.

title: West Pier by Gavin Dunbar
text:
West Pier by Gavin Dunbar
We love Gavin’s dramatic image of West Pier in Brighton. Using a long exposure has smoothed out the seas and sky, and making the image black and white gives the skeleton structure of the burnt out pier even more impact.

title: Untitled by Diego Epstein
text:
Untitled by Diego Epstein
This natural street portrait was taken using a wide aperture to blur out the background, creating a nice bokeh and drawing your eye to the model, who is positioned comfortably toward the left of the image.

title: On by David Talley
text:
On by David Talley
“This is another piece I shot over the weekend while I was visiting some friends in Santa Barbara, and an idea I’ve had in my head since early summer. On this day, we woke up at 4:30 AM and drove up to a rocky, mountainous area overlooking Santa Barbara’s beaches and the island just offshore. It was 35 degrees outside, and one of the most amazing views I’ve ever seen. We spent the rest of the day tripping around beaches, cliffs, and fields until it was time to depart for home. The past weekend was an unforgettable experience!” – David Talley

title: Passenger Seat by Paige Nelson
text:
Passenger Seat by Paige Nelson
“I used a technique called expansion to make this photo larger. The original photo is of my torso up. I panned my camera around the surrounding area and stitched the photo together in Photoshop.”

title: Every Wednesday we feature the very best photography that has been shared to our Facebook page.

Every Wednesday we feature the very best photography that has been shared to our Facebook page.

title: Winter’s Tale in Moscow by Irina Mastalyarchuk
text:
Winter’s Tale in Moscow by Irina Mastalyarchuk
This image beautifully captures a cold winter’s night in Moscow. The composition follows the rule of thirds as the subject is positioned off-centre. While the subject’s gaze is fixed toward the left side of the picture, she is positioned on the right so that her gaze can be comfortably followed into the open space of the image. The shallow depth of field creates a picturesque bokeh of city lights as the background to this portrait.

title: Evening Shade by Jesse Ray
text:
Evening Shade by Jesse Ray
This thoughtfully composed picture perfectly draws attention to the delicate yellow flower standing alone in an otherwise somewhat bleak environment. It is a simple yet strong image that suggests hope and optimism.

title: Cathedral Glow by Aaron Meyers
text:
Cathedral Glow by Aaron Meyers
“I hiked 10 miles with the flu to get this shot of the sun reflecting on Cathedral Peak in Yosemite National Park, in California. Most of my images involve some sort of sunset or sunrise, and I love catching all the colour that occurs at this time.” – Aaron Meyers

title: Himalaya #10 by Lukas Kozmus
text:
Himalaya #10 by Lukas Kozmus 
Lukas says of this photograph:

title: Mitten Trails by John Davis
text:
Mitten Trails by John Davis
This fantastic shot by John was submitted to our night photography challenge on our Facebook page. This is a different perspective on a famous landscape which is also a popular spot to photograph. Shooting at night to capture the light trail of a passing car on the valley floor and the star trails over Monument Valley adds a dramatic element to an already stunning landscape.

title: Untitled by Angela Fanton
text:
Untitled by Angela Fanton
This photograph has been carefully edited and considered to create the soft feel of the final image.

text:
Every Wednesday we feature the very best photography that has been shared to our Facebook page. Click on the images to see these fantastic photographs in full.
Like us on Facebook and share your work with us for the chance to be featured here and in the magazine!

title: For you! Thank you! by Ewa Ciebiera
text:
For you! Thank you! by Ewa Ciebiera
This macro shot is simple and elegant. The extreme shallow depth of field focuses solely on the flower in the centre of the image, drawing your attention to the small drops of water on its petals, and the delicate pattern of its veins. Here the photographer has expertly got you to pay attention to, look closely at, and see the beauty in an otherwise ordinary plant that is all too easy to overlook.

title: Disconnected by Carlos Resende
text:
Disconnected by Carlos Resende
The soft blur of the sea and clouds, lighting, and pastel colours combine to create an other-worldliness to this image. The crooked pier guides your eye to the lights on the horizon, which are framed within the picture by the wooden structure toward the centre of the image. Well composed and thoughtfully edited, this is a seascape to be proud of.

title: Small steps, big dreams by Tomasz Lemisiewicz
text:
Small steps, big dreams by Tomasz Lemisiewicz
This unusual image was captured on a Nikon D90 and then had textures added to it in post-processing. The shallow depth of field means that the footsteps in the snow are sharply in focus, while both the foreground and background remain out of focus, and as such your eye is drawn neatly into the centre. Although the trees in the background are blurred, they retain their distinguished shape and are instantly recognisable as conifer trees, so although only a very small part of the image is in focus, the combined elements of snow, trees, and the colour treatment come together to create the perfect winter scene.

title: Lupin Rising by Christian Lim
text:
Lupin Rising by Christian Lim
This image of a field of lupins makes the most of the warm, natural light of the sunset, which serves to light up the flowers and make their colours more vibrant. A perfect example of how shooting into the sun can often yield good results.

title: In the tube by Nicolas Le Boulanger
text:
In the tube by Nicolas Le Boulanger
With the foreground and background blurred and the fox in perfect focus, your eye is effortlessly drawn to the main subject of this image. The photograph is also well composed with the fox slightly off-centre and positioned just on the horizon of the grassy path and framed between the tall ferns; it is also set apart further by the lighter background directly behind the fox.

title: Come by Magdalena Berny
text:
Come by Magdalena Berny
This unusual portait by Magdalena is both compelling and a little unnerving. The expression and gaze of the child gives you the impression that she is looking directly at you as she walks into the dark woods, drawing you further into the picture. Although this was clearly taken on a dull day, Magdalena has managed to keep her subject well lit, making her stand out against the background and giving the shot more impact.

title: Storm by Daniel Bosma
text:
Storm by Daniel Bosma
The photographer’s decision to make this image black and white was a very good move, as the sharp, striking shape of the rocks against the white mist of the sea spray in the foreground, and the rock structure jutting out of the sea on the horizon, are made all the more distinctive, and even a little bit intimidating!

title: The Boathouse by Mark Littlejohn
text:
The Boathouse by Mark Littlejohn 
The purple tones in the sky and the fog hovering on the horizon of the lake work together to soften this image. We like the sharpness of the grasses in the foreground, and the subtle lighting on the house on the right.

title: Luke & Butterfly Meet Again by Jessica Kirste
text:
Luke & Butterfly Meet Again by Jessica Kirste
Playful, innocent, and charming, this lovely portrait of a dog watching a butterfly can’t fail but reach the soft-spot in all of us. The composition is well executed, drawing your eye to the butterfly, following the dog’s gaze.

title: Encosto by Anna Theodora
text:
Encosto by Anna Theodora
We love Anna’s unique shot; from the nostalgic colour treatment, to the compelling composition. The image is interestingly divided between the worn textures of the wall and the colourful skyline at the top, which sets the scene. The mysterious cloaked figures give a surreal, fun, and surprising angle what would otherwise be an ordinary urban scene.

title: Blazing Dusk by Steve Docwra
text:
Blazing Dusk by Steve Docwra
This calming seascape makes the most of the vibrant pink of the clouds, giving it a somewhat surreal quality against the dark blues of the sea and sky.

title: The way ahead by Angela Fanton
text:
The way ahead by Angela Fanton
This image - instantly recognisable as a Venetian scene - is a shot that epitomises travel photography. The perspective from the gondola itself places you in the scene and pulls you into the picture. The shallow depth of field adds to this effect as the way it renders perspective is similar to that of the human eye.

text:
Every Wednesday we feature the very best photography that has been shared to our Facebook page over the past week. Click on the images to see these fantastic photographs in full.
Like us on Facebook and share your work with us for the chance to be featured here and in the magazine!

title: Birthday by Oleg Oprisco
text:
Birthday by Oleg Oprisco
This interesting portrait has the graininess of film and the warm colours are reminiscent of an older photograph. Together with the model’s pensive expression, this makes for an intriguing shot that leave the viewer wondering what the story is behind this picture.

title: Far Out by Rohan Reilly
text:
Far Out by Rohan Reilly
The composition of this image is superb; it almost appears geometrically perfect. It must surely be an image that mathematicians would love! The long exposure smooths out the sea and clouds and leaves you to focus entirely on the lines and angles of the jetty, which pulls you into the centre of the image.

title: By Fiona Sami
text:
By Fiona Sami
Fiona’s still life has the feel of a classic painting, aided by the textures that have been added in post-processing. The image largely relies on the simply beauty of the flower itself; the background remains plain so there is no distraction from the subject. Simple, beautiful, well-executed, this is an elegant image that would look at home framed and hanging on a wall.

title: Cinematic Skies by Aaron Fuhrman
text:
Cinematic Skies by Aaron Fuhrman
Aaron tells us that he took this image on an otherwise routine drive home from his work. A great example of why it pays to keep your camera handy at all times!

title: Trapped by Fakrul J
text:
Trapped by Fakrul J
This eerie image by Fakrul is of mangrove roots growing along the seashore. We love how the long exposure has levelled out the horizon and smoothed out the clouds, offering a nice contrast to the  jagged edges of the roots. Converting to mono was the perfect choice for this image.

title: By Sarah Ann Loreth
text:
By Sarah Ann Loreth
The composition and focusing in this picture are spot on, and the shallow depth of field  combined with the lens flare from the sun makes for an enchanting picture of an otherwise plain subject matter.

Every Wednesday we feature the very best photography that has been shared to our Facebook page over the past week. Click on the images to see these fantastic photographs in full.

title: From A Place of Hope by Larri Cochran
text:
From A Place of Hope by Larri Cochran
The shallow depth of field in this picture creates an effect that makes it appear almost like a painting. The limited colour palette of red, orange and green and the application of the rule of thirds composition helps to make this a bold image.

title: Forsaken by Lincoln Harrison
text:
Forsaken by Lincoln Harrison
Not only are the colours fantastic in this mesmerising star trail photograph, but the silhouette of the tree aligned against the centre point of the star trails makes this even more of an impressive image.

title: Resting Place by Darren Moore
text:
Resting Place by Darren Moore
This long-exposure mono image gives an almost surreal quality to this scene. The jagged edges of the wrecked boat jutting out of the water seems imposing against the apparent stillness of the water. The dark of the sky and the vignette further help to focus attention on the boat.

title: Radha Krishna - The Immortal Love Legends by Amlan Sanyal
text:
Radha Krishna - The Immortal Love Legends by Amlan Sanyal
This eye-catching portrait has a fantastic use of colour; the green background compliments the pink and blue face paint of the women well, while their serious expressions make the image captivating.

title: Saxony by Dietrich Bojko
text:
Saxony by Dietrich Bojko
Dietrich took this shot of the Lillenstein countryside at 5.30am, and it was certainly worth the early start. The early morning mist has been caught in a pink light by the rising sun, giving a very soft feel to the image. The colours because more pastel in tone toward the top of the image, as the mist softens the landscape in the distance. Gorgeous.

title: In issue 7 of Photography Week we interviewed overnight photographic sensation Seth Casteel whose quirky photographs of dogs jumping into a swimming pool went viral!
text:
In issue 7 of Photography Week we interviewed overnight photographic sensation Seth Casteel whose quirky photographs of dogs jumping into a swimming pool went viral! 
Read our interview with Seth.

title: By Saud A. Faisal
text:
By Saud A. Faisal
Saud’s portrait of a Chinese man smoking a pipe makes great use of light and shadow. The vignette frames the man well, while his face remains lit. The intense blacks of the image add a contrast, giving the impression of deep wrinkles on that subject, and makes this image more striking.

title: Red Deer Stag by Neil Neville
text:
Red Deer Stag by Neil Neville
This silhouette is instantly recognisable as a stag in rut, and as such makes this a very strong image. Getting out early to shoot in this location certainly paid off as the mist has yet to be burnt away by the sun, and the rich colours of sunrise still remain. We also love the soft focus of the foreground, while the stag is sharply in focus.

title: Every Wednesday we feature the very best photography that has been shared to our Facebook page over the past week. Click on the images to see these fantastic photographs in full.
text:
Every Wednesday we feature the very best photography that has been shared to our Facebook page over the past week. Click on the images to see these fantastic photographs in full.
Like us on Facebook and share your work with us for the chance to be featured here and in the magazine!

title: Solid by António Bagorro
text:
Solid by António Bagorro
This strong landscape photograph makes an impact with the unusual-shaped stone dominating the scene. The deep blacks contrast with the highlights on the stone, making it more striking still. The sharpness of this contrasts well against the soft blur of the sea, giving a good balance to the image of hard and soft, and light and shadow.

title: Mountain Ibex - Chamonix, French Alps by Örvar Atli Þorgeirsson
text:
Mountain Ibex - Chamonix, French Alps by Örvar Atli Þorgeirsson
The photographer was lucky to capture these ibex just at the perfect moment. Not only are the clearly energetic ibex sharply in focus, but the composition is good too. The ibex on the right is perfectly positioned within the ‘V’ shape of the mountain range behind, and the lighter colours of the distance mountains make it even more prominent.

title: Breakfast with chocolate & cranberry madeleine by Anna Verdina
text:
Breakfast with chocolate & cranberry madeleine by Anna Verdina
It is clear to see that a lot of time, effort, and consideration has gone into the set-up and composition of this photograph. We get the impression that the positioning of the table arrangement – down to every last berry – has been meticulously thought out. This photograph aims to create an inviting scene that lures you in; that makes you want to reach right into the picture and pick up a madeleine. This is what good food photography is all about.

title: Breath of Autumn by ’Danired’
text:
Breath of Autumn by ’Danired’
With the sun shining through and lighting the cobwebs on the heather, we can’t help but think of a crisp autumnal morning. We love the bokeh and the curve of the cobwebs which lies in line with the curve of light in the background.

title: Intactness by Jessica Ellen
text:
Intactness by Jessica Ellen
Wow. This is an image with real impact, and as a portrait it’s very unusual. We think it works because the lighting is just spot-on; the girl is perfectly lit within the smoke from the fire, and any background distractions are almost non-existant due to the heavy vignetting which renders the background very dark.

title: 或る実る光 by Tomoyuki Shinohara
text:
或る実る光 by Tomoyuki Shinohara
This image is slightly overexposed, but we believe that photography rules are made to be broken and in this case, the fact that it is overexposed adds to the dream-like quality of the picture. The subtle sun-flare and out-of-focus grasses in the foreground create a wonderfully soft feel to this image, while the figure of the girl in the distance surrounded by the long grass provides an air of mystery. All-in-all, this is an enchanting photograph.

text:
Every Wednesday we feature the very best photography that has been shared to our Facebook page over the past week. Click on the images to see these fantastic photographs in full.
Like us on Facebook and share your work with us for the chance to be featured here and in the magazine! Our special thanks this week to Gunnlaugur Örn Valsson, HyunJung Jung, Kazuhito Takenaka and Simon Goyne.

title: Manhattanhenge on May 31, 2012 by Steven Kelley
text:
Manhattanhenge on May 31, 2012 by Steven Kelley
With all that New York City has seen recently after she has been battered and bruised by Hurricane Sandy, we felt it was apt to make this image our Photo of the Day.

title: Lagarfljót by Brian Rueb
text:
Lagarfljót by Brian Rueb
The abandoned house neatly sits at the point of the image where a sea of colours converge; the pastel colours of the sky, the milky white of the water, the grey of the stone, and the green of the grass. This, together with its off-centred position, allows your eye to fall straight to the house as the main subject of the image, whilst instantly getting the most of the vibrant colours. It’s a colour-feast for the eyes.

title: Dawn at Nash Point by Jeff Morgan
text:
Dawn at Nash Point by Jeff Morgan
The long-exposure here has created the impression of a perfectly calm sea. Getting up early to capture the dawn light was certainly worthwhile as the soft pastel colours of the sunrise provide a nice contrast to the cold blue tones of the foreground. We also like the subtle vignette, which helps to draw your eye to the lighter part of the sea just off centre of the image.

title: Beautiful Chaos by Shane Black
text:
Beautiful Chaos by Shane Black
Thanks to careful and clever compositing, Shane’s image has real drama and impact. The location of each brick has been considered, and a lot of thought has gone into which bricks should be in crisp focus, and which should be blurred. Overall it creates a feel of real depth, drawing you in. The direction of the model’s hair also mirrors that of the bricks, giving you the sensation that everything in the image is slowing taking off and lifting up into the air. Fantastic.

title: 17: Life by Steven Chan
text:
17: Life by Steven Chan
We love the composition of this image; the train tracks guide your eye into the centre of the image, drawing you further in. The blue in the sky and the green of the fields could be bright and vibrant, however they have been edited so that the tones appear slightly desaturated and muted colours are muted, creating a somewhat pensive feel to this landscape scene.

title: Changing Leaves by David LaMason
text:
Changing Leaves by David LaMason
Autumn is truly here, and we couldn’t resist putting up an image that celebrates the brief explosion of colour that the season is famous for. We’ve chosen this image as we love how the strong colours contrast with each other, making the red of the leaf even more vivid.

title: Rocco – Boston Terrier by Seth Casteel
text:
Rocco – Boston Terrier by Seth Casteel
We couldn’t not feature one of the fantastic pet portraits of lifestyle pet photographer Seth Casteel as our Photo of the Day. His photographs of dogs jumping into water went viral and were soon to be seen in many places around the Internet. Fun and accessible, this is photography that everyone can enjoy.

title: Every Wednesday we feature the very best photography that has been shared to our Facebook page over the past week. Click on the images to see these fantastic photographs in full.
text:
Every Wednesday we feature the very best photography that has been shared to our Facebook page over the past week. Click on the images to see these fantastic photographs in full.
Like us on Facebook and share your work with us for the chance to be featured here and in the magazine! Our special thanks this week to Dustin Abbott, Toni F. Mestres and Zill Niazi.

title: Is There Something In My Teeth? by Natalie Webb
text:
Is There Something In My Teeth? by Natalie Webb
Yawning? Or roaring? It’s hard to say which the young lion is doing here, but we like to think that this is a roar, summing up that infamous and dramatic sound of the savannah. Apart from those fabulous teeth, we like how the grasses frame the lion’s face so well.

title: Tram Memories by Leonardo Correa Luna
text:
Tram Memories by Leonardo Correa Luna
Street photography is all about capturing people going about their daily lives and small moments in time, and this shot taken in Hong Kong has certainly done just that. The angle, although quirky, is fun and playful. We love that the pedestrians on the street in the background remain blurred, minimising distractions from the mother and child on the tram who are sharply in focus. The woman’s smile and her hair blowing in the wind add something of a movie-scene romance to the picture. The child’s calm expression and focus on the photographer holds your attention and draws you further into the picture. Beautiful.

title: Clifton Suspension Bridge by ‘Razmo12’
text:
Clifton Suspension Bridge by ‘Razmo12’
This postcard-perfect picture of Clifton Suspension Bridge is an instant eye-catcher. The dramatic sunset provides the perfect backdrop to the bridge, while the light reflected in the river beneath it brightens up the bottom half of the image.

title: Enchanted Forest by Dustin Abbott
text:
Enchanted Forest by Dustin Abbott
This image by Dustin Abbott perfectly encapsulates a cold day in late autumn, with the low fog creating an eerie quality to the scene. We like that the way the avenue of trees lead your eye into the centre, where the misty opening suggests an air of mystery.

title: Whitley Bay Sunset by Darren Irwin
text:
Whitley Bay Sunset by Darren Irwin
Aah, an image to welcome in the weekend if ever we saw one! The composition is inch-perfect, the colours are stunning and the exposure is spot-on, with the bright sky and dark foreground perfectly balanced. We love the careful placement of the reflection on the right, too.

title: Atlantic Puffin, the Isle of May, Fife, Scotland by Ian Cowe
text:
Atlantic Puffin, the Isle of May, Fife, Scotland by Ian Cowe
Photographing wildlife in direct sunlight can be quite challenging, as it often results in detail-free highlights or shadows. Get it right, though, and it can be really effective, as Ian’s stunning shot shows. We especially like the background blur, the beak’s shadow and the slightly forlorn expression in the puffin’s eyes.

title: Every Wednesday we feature the very best photography that has been shared to our Facebook page over the past week. Click on the images to see these fantastic photographs in full.
text:
Every Wednesday we feature the very best photography that has been shared to our Facebook page over the past week. Click on the images to see these fantastic photographs in full.
Like us on Facebook and share your work with us for the chance to be featured here and in the magazine!

title: By Vicky Morin
text:
By Vicky Morin
Here in the UK, summer is well and truly giving way to autumn, so we thought we’d go with something seasonal for today’s photo. It’s the warm, muted colour palette that really sets this images apart - that, and the sense of decay, and the passing of time…

title: Mantauk Sunrise by Xun Wang
text:
Mantauk Sunrise by Xun Wang
There’s something about backlit boulders slick with water that never fails to impress, but Xun Wang’s sublime seascape takes things to a whole new level. We especially love the warm colours in the sky, and the fact that the light from the lighthouse lines up so precisely with the line between the bright sky and the dark cloud.

title: Sun Showers, Loch Arkaig by Angus Clyne
text:
Sun Showers, Loch Arkaig by Angus Clyne
With its foreboding clouds and distant, snow-clad mountains, this really is the road to nowhere. Angus’s image has everything you could want in a landscape: strong light, bags of contrast and detail, a pixel-perfect composition, and strong leading lines coming in from the corners. Simply stunning.

title: Le Parking by Lotfi Dakhli
text:
Le Parking by Lotfi Dakhli
The most effective images are often the simplest - though that doesn’t mean they’re simple to take. We love the subtle lighting, muted colour palette and lovely background blur in this low-key location portrait. The pillars and lights frame the subject perfectly, with the latter leading the eye into the frame.

title: Tarn Hows III by Peter Ribbeck
text:
Tarn Hows III by Peter Ribbeck
How about this for in image to welcome in the weekend? The soft, warm lighting; the slight asymmetry; the mist in the distant valleys echoing the water in the foreground; all of these elements combine to create something really quite magical. Oh, and the square crop works a treat, too.

title: Clear and Cold by Amelia Fletcher
text:
Clear and Cold by Amelia Fletcher
Inspired by yesterday’s reader images, here’s another highly original portrait. Despite the movement of the model’s hair, this image has a still, restful feel about it, thanks in part to the powder that’s been frozen by the high-speed flash. It almost looks like a veil falling down over her face.

title: Every Wednesday we feature the very best photography that has been shared to our Facebook page over the past week. Click on the images to see these fantastic photographs in full.
text:
Every Wednesday we feature the very best photography that has been shared to our Facebook page over the past week. Click on the images to see these fantastic photographs in full.
Like us on Facebook and share your work with us for the chance to be featured here and in the magazine!

title: Light and Shade by Carmen Morosan
text:
Light and Shade by Carmen Morosan
There’s more to this apparently simple image than meets the eye. With the bull almost lost in shadow, and the matador bathed in sunlight, the two adversaries are linked by the strong diagonal that cuts right across the frame.

title: How Hill by Geoff Tibbenham
text:
How Hill by Geoff Tibbenham
A lovely, tranquil image to get the week off to a relaxing start! We especially like the subtle colours of the clouds in the sky, and the sense that the water’s edge is receding into the distant haze.

title: Toes by Noelle Buske
text:
Toes by Noelle Buske
This is a great example of a tight crop taken to extremes. The soft light, the muted colours and the beautiful foreground bokeh all combine to create an image that is greater than the sum of its parts. Another wish-you-were-there gem.

title: In the Midst of it All by Carolyn Cochrane
text:
In the Midst of it All by Carolyn Cochrane
Here’s a beautifully backlit image to brighten up your weekend. It’s hard to put your finger on what makes this shot so special - the composition doesn’t obey any of the ‘rules’, the background is deliberately over-exposed, and the subject is pretty everyday - but somehow it just works.

title: Providence by Rob Macklin
text:
Providence by Rob Macklin
How about this to welcome in the weekend? Rob’s image has a real wish-you-were-there quality, thanks to the immediacy of the flowers in the foreground, the warm light on the distant peaks, and the leading lines of the tree-clad slopes in between.

title: To fade in and nothing else by Sophia Alexis
text:
To fade in and nothing else by Sophia Alexis
Location portraits taken from low viewpoint, and with the foreground blurred out, seem to be all the rage at the moment, and Sophia’s image is a brilliantly executed example. With shots like this the danger is the subject getting lost in the foreground, or background, or both, but here the model’s wistful gaze is perfectly captured in the soft, early-morning light.

title: Every Wednesday we feature the very best photography that has been shared to our Facebook page over the past week. Click on the images to see these fantastic photographs in full.
text:
Every Wednesday we feature the very best photography that has been shared to our Facebook page over the past week. Click on the images to see these fantastic photographs in full.
Like us on Facebook and share your work with us for the chance to be featured here and in the magazine!

title: Mundo azul by Luis Gonzalez
text:
Mundo azul by Luis Gonzalez
This stunning macro shot by Luis Gonzalez is perfectly composed and beautifully lit, but as the title suggests, it’s the muted blue colour palette of the background that really makes it.

title: Corfe Castle by Mike Byford
text:
Corfe Castle by Mike Byford
Here’s something to brighten up your Monday! Corfe Castle in Dorset, UK, is a popular subject, but it’s not often you see it captured in an image as accomplished and atmospheric as this. We especially like contrast between the cool blues on the left and the warmer colours on the right.

title: Rays by Marcin Sobas
text:
Rays by Marcin Sobas
From bright and breezy to mean and moody. A quick glance at Marcin’s on-line portfolio (see below) shows that he is a master of mist and side-lighting, and in this stunning shot they’ve been combined to great effect.

title: Miri by Jack Batchelor
text:
Miri by Jack Batchelor
We’re often advised to avoid symmetry when photographing people, but in this breezy image by portrait specialist Jack Batchelor, positioning the model at the centre of the frame has resulted in a really striking composition. We also like the blurred flowers, the subdued colours and the deliberate vignetting in the corners, which combine to give the finished image a satisfyingly low-fi feel.

title: Cape Kiwanda by Bill Ratcliffe
text:
Cape Kiwanda by Bill Ratcliffe
Capturing the power and energy of the sea in a still image is a real challenge, so we’re grateful to Bill Ratcliffe for showing us how it’s done…! The key to a shot like this is the timing of the exposure, and ensuring that the shutter is open as the waves are receding rather than breaking, as this creates a sense of movement as the spent waves suck back over the rocks.

title: Black Eyed Susan by Jacob Edmiston
text:
Black Eyed Susan by Jacob Edmiston
Jacob’s ultra-vibrant image of a black-eyed Susan, which has to be viewed large to be fully appreciated, provides a masterclass in the use of complementary colours. The vivid yellow really stands out against the cobalt-blue of the blurred background, and this blue is echoed in the tightly-packed carpels at the centre of the flower.

title: Every Wednesday we feature the very best photography that has been shared to our Facebook page over the past week. Click on the images to see these fantastic photographs in full.
text:
Every Wednesday we feature the very best photography that has been shared to our Facebook page over the past week. Click on the images to see these fantastic photographs in full.
Like us on Facebook and share your work with us for the chance to be featured here and in the magazine!

title: The Cabin by Mathijs Delva
text:
The Cabin by Mathijs Delva
This lovely, late-summer image by Mathijs Delva was taken at 11pm using an ND filter and an exposure time of 50 seconds. The result is an image as serene as it is tranquil. We especially like the splash of vivid red on the cabin, and the subtle movement in the dusky clouds.

title: Beach Bum by Molly Strohl
text:
Beach Bum by Molly Strohl
We thought we’d kick off the week with this bright and breezy beach portrait by fine art photographer Molly Strohl. By shooting on a hazy day at an aperture of f/1.4, Molly has produced an image that almost has a tilt-shift feel to it. We like everything about it, from the square crop and finely balanced composition to the soft lighting and muted colour palette.

title: The Morning Mirage by Daniel Cheong
text:
The Morning Mirage by Daniel Cheong
This jewel-like cityscape by Daniel Cheong is so packed with colour and detail that it looks like something from a science fiction film. Positioning the city in the very middle of the frame is a masterstroke, as it makes the most of the colour and space above and below the horizon, while the foreground detail that’s just visible below the surface of the water makes it look like it’s floating.

title: Summer Bliss by Thuy Nguyen
text:
Summer Bliss by Thuy Nguyen
It’s rare to find an image of something as simple as a fence photographed so creatively and colourfully. Unusually for a close-up, Thuy’s image works because of, rather than in spite of, the strong, direct lighting. The contrast between the bright sky and leaves and the dark fence and trees really helps tie the composition together, but the highlight - if you’ll excuse the pun - is the sparkling bokeh in the background. Summer bliss indeed!

title: What’s up there? by Claire Marshall
text:
What’s up there? by Claire Marshall
Owls are typically photographed straight on, eyeballing the camera, so it’s refreshing to see an image that captures animal behaviour rather than animal posing. Traditionalists might argue that the crop could be tighter, but we like the square crop, the use of negative space to focus attention on the subject, and the suggestion of the wider world beyond the edges of the frame. The slow shutter speed has also blurred the falling raindrops nicely…

title: Step Out and Face the Storm by Gurbir Grewal
text:
Step Out and Face the Storm by Gurbir Grewal 
Portraits don’t always have to be taken at close quarters. Here a conceptual approach pays dividends, with the juxtaposition of subject with elemental forces suggestive of being at harmony with nature. The minimal colour palette further enhances the mood. A willing model is, of course, a pre-requisite.

title: At Photography Week we feature the very best photography that has been shared to our Facebook page. Click on the images to see these fantastic photographs in full.
text:
At Photography Week we feature the very best photography that has been shared to our Facebook page. Click on the images to see these fantastic photographs in full.
Like us on Facebook and share your work with us for the chance to be featured here and in the magazine!

title: Llanddwyn Island off Anglesey by Stephen McNally
text:
Llanddwyn Island off Anglesey by Stephen McNally
Strong lead-in lines always draw the viewer’s attention towards a subject and here the technique is used in conjunction with the rule of thirds to create a memorable composition. The pathway pulls the eye towards the lighthouse, which is nestling perfectly at a rule of thirds intersection point. The exposure’s not bad either!

title: Pardon Me by Amanda Tipton
text:
Pardon Me by Amanda Tipton
The key to a successful pet portrait lies in capturing the character of the animal in question. This witty shot appears to break the rules by focusing on the dog’s nose instead of the eyes, but it really allows the animal’s personality to come across. The artistic feel of the black and white conversion suggests an animal of great character as well as playfulness.

title: Bolinas Ridge Sunset by David Shield
text:
Bolinas Ridge Sunset by David Shield
There’s always a risk when you deliberately include lens flare in an image that it will look like a mistake, or simply prove too distracting; but when it works, it really works. David’s superb shot of the gently rolling hills of Mount Tamalpais leading up to Salinas Ridge in California unfolds like a stage set, with layer after layer leading the eye to the ridge on the horizon, and the burst of light from the rising sun.

title: Untitled by Laura Zalenga
text:
Untitled by Laura Zalenga
Subtle lighting, beautiful bokeh and a muted colour palette are the keys to this striking portrait by Laura Zalenga. The model’s face is perfectly framed, and although her eyes are in shadow, there’s just enough of a catch-light to provide a point of focus, and draw the viewer in.

title: dubai.aerial.one by Johannes Heuckeroth
text:
dubai.aerial.one by Johannes Heuckeroth
This is Dubai as you’ve never seen it before: bright, white and almost completely bleached out. It’s as you’d imagine a city in the middle of the desert to look on a 40-degree day, complete with hazy sky and barely visible cumulus clouds. The result is more like an architectural drawing, or an artist’s impression, than a photograph.

title: Snail and the Raindrop by Vadim Trunov
text:
Snail and the Raindrop by Vadim Trunov
The great thing about photography is that just when you think you’ve seen it all, along comes an image that makes you shake your head in wonder. We’ve no idea how Vadim got this shot, and - for once  - we’re not even sure we want to know. We’re just glad he did. Click on the image to enlarge it, and prepare to be amazed…

title: Bardenas Storm by Martin Zalba
text:
Bardenas Storm by Martin Zalba
Slow shutter-speed cloudscapes are becoming increasingly popular, but Martin’s image of a massive storm cell over Bardenes Reales in Spain is one of the best we’ve seen – not least because of the technical challenges of capturing a very long exposure and a split-second (and wholly unpredictable) bolt of lighting in the same frame. Thanks to the long exposure, the cloud looks as if it’s being sucked into a giant vortex, while the deep blues and vivid reds add a real sense of drama.

title: Alpe di Siusi Morning Sun by Hans Kruse
text:
Alpe di Siusi Morning Sun by Hans Kruse
Here’s a nice sunny image to start the week, and what an image! Hans’ shot works on so many levels that it’s hard to know where to begin. The composition provides a masterclass in the rule of thirds, every element is perfectly exposed, and the layering of the elements, from the trees in the foreground to the distant hills, creates a real sense of depth. A classic wish-you-were-there photo…

title: Untitled by Elizabeth Gadd
text:
Untitled by Elizabeth Gadd
Here at Photography Week we’re big fans of backlighting, and Elizabeth’s stunning self-portrait makes brilliant use of it, from the rim-light around her hair to the tendrils of fog that give the image its whimsical, fairy-tale feel. We can only imagine how tricky it must have been to expose this shot…

title: By Mark Bridger
text:
By Mark Bridger
Mark has a fantastic collection of owl images on his website, but none are as memorable or charming as this one. It’s technically spot on, with the foreground and background nicely blurred, and the catchlights in the owl’s eyes pin-sharp, but it’s the owl’s pose as it peeps out from behind the tree that makes it such a stand-out image.

title: Flame and Horsehead Nebula by John Biondo
text:
Flame and Horsehead Nebula by John Biondo
You don’t need a giant radio telescope and a degree in astrophysics to get stunning images of outer space, as this shot of the Horsehead Nebula shows. Taking using a humble Nikon D90 and a (relatively) modest, 4.5 inch refractor telescope, it was created by combining fifteen 45-second exposures taken at ISO800 in Photoshop CS5. It boasts a staggering level of colour and detail, and really needs to be viewed full-screen to be fully appreciated.

title: The Cascade by Brad Wagner
text:
The Cascade by Brad Wagner
Brad’s image of photographer Brendon Burton in Glacier National Park, Montana, is an environmental portrait par excellence. The lighting is subtle but punchy, the near-symmetrical composition is spot-on, and the blurred foreground gives the whole image a slightly mysterious, dream-like quality. And that’s quite apart from the technical challenges of shooting from what must have been inches above the surface of the stream…

title: La Serenissima by Saskia Etschmaier
text:
La Serenissima by Saskia Etschmaier
Here at Photography Week, we love images that make us look twice, and Saskia’s themed fashion shot really rewards careful viewing. At first glance, it’s hard to get a grip on the perspective, but gradually the blurred foreground and the sweep of the spiral staircase draw the viewer into the image, and straight to the model’s intense gaze. Her gold dress complements the greens in the stone nicely, too.

title: Shafts of Light over the Eden Valley by Steve Thompson
text:
Shafts of Light over the Eden Valley by Steve Thompson
Shafts of sunlight breaking through the clouds are much harder to photograph than they look, and getting it right is usually a case of being in the right place at the right time. Steve’s shot of the Eden Valley in the UK has it all, from the shafts of light going all the way to the edges of the frame to the fantastic details in the sun-dappled landscape. The ominous clouds and dark foreground also frame the shot nicely.

title: Caracal Kitten by Arman Werth
text:
Caracal Kitten by Arman Werth
Sometimes, a shot’s subject is what really makes it stand out, and this is a case in point. Arman’s photo of a caracal kitten is technically very accomplished, with the kitten’s eyes and fur pin-sharp, and the soft green background nicely blurred, but it’s the kitten’s fantastic ears, and its slightly doleful eyes, that make this such an eye-catching photo.

title: Just Passing Through by Gary Randall
text:
Just Passing Through by Gary Randall
Capturing a winning image of the milky way, the aurora borealis or a shooting star is challenging enough, but to capture all three in the same frame, and so perfectly arranged, is a real feat. Gary’s shot shows a rare display of the aurora borealis at Trillium Lake in Oregon, while a shooting star slices through the star-spangled sky.

title: Sleep of Gwenhwyfar by Sarah Ann Wright
text:
Sleep of Gwenhwyfar by Sarah Ann Wright
Portrait photography doesn’t have to be literal, as this highly theatrical and beautifully executed image illustrates. Here, Welsh goddess Gwenhywfar, believed by many to have become the mortal Queen Guinevere, wife of King Arthur, is perfectly framed by a bower of red roses, which echo the blood-red colour of her lips. This, combined with the pure white of her robes and the deep black of her eyelashes, makes for a very graphic shot.

title: Takeoff by Bob Jensen
text:
Takeoff by Bob Jensen
Getting macro shots of insects as sharp as this is hard enough when the subject is static, but to do it when the subject is mid-flight is something else. Bob’s image of an assassin fly alighting on buckwheat blossom has it all: pin-sharp eyes, a beautifully blurred background, and just enough motion blur in the wings to provide a sense of movement. Oh, and the composition’s spot on, too.

title: Moonrise in Manarola by Dan Carr
text:
Moonrise in Manarola by Dan Carr
Italian hill-top towns are typically photographed in colour, and under blazing Mediterranean-blue skies, so it’s refreshing to see one shot at night, and converted so brilliantly to black and white. Composition-wise, the shimmering whites of the crashing waves in the bottom right neatly echo the bright facades of the buildings at the top left, and the twinkling lights of the town and moon give the whole image an inviting, romantic feel.

title: What are you looking at? by Tom Kruissink
text:
What are you looking at? by Tom Kruissink
It’s not often that you see a kingfisher image as colourful and well-crafted as this one. The soft, subtle lighting has resulted in exquisite colour and detailing in the bird’s plumage, and has provided a lovely catchlight in its eye. Our favourite element, though, is the beautifully blurred water that’s rushing past in the background.

title: Off to the Barn by Todd Klassy
text:
Off to the Barn by Todd Klassy
Todd Klassy’s image of two cowgirls leading their horses home near Havre, Montana, is so well executed, and the composition so carefully considered, that it stands head and shoulders above most sunset silhouettes. The separation of the horses and riders is inch-perfect, the framing provides a masterclass in the rule of thirds, and the colours in the sky are simply stunning. But it’s the subtle sunburst just kissing the tip of the front horse’s hoof that really makes it.

title: Wish you were here by Toma EvsuVdo
text:
Wish you were here by Toma EvsuVdo
Here at Photography Week we browse hundreds – if not thousands – of images every week, and it’s not often that we see a waterscape as original as this one. It’s hard to pick out our favourite bits of Toma’s sublime photo as there are so many, but we love the beautiful bokeh, the perfectly balanced composition, and the fact that the little wavelet is just on the point of peeling over. We also like the first comment on the shot’s Flickr page, which sums it up rather well: “Holyfocusbokehandtones!”

title: Cloud City by Sebastian Optiz
text:
Cloud City by Sebastian Optiz
Sebastian’s stunning shot of Dubai on a foggy morning provides a perfect example of why it’s so important to wait for the right light and weather conditions when photographing cityscapes. Without the fog this would simply be a nice, blue-sky aerial shot, but with it the whole scene is transformed into something altogether more mesmerising. We especially like the careful arrangement of the skyscrapers within the frame, and the way that the low, early-morning light gives the buildings a wonderfully crisp, three-dimensional feel.

title: Lion at the WHF by Linda M
text:
Lion at the WHF by Linda M
Linda’s image of a wounded lion at the Wildlife Heritage Foundation in Kent, UK, takes the term ‘animal portrait’ to a whole new level. “He’d just had a disagreement with his brother and he came off worst,” explains Linda. “I think his pride, along with the cut on his nose, was a little hurt!”

title: Rolling Mist by Martin Rak
text:
Rolling Mist by Martin Rak
Martin’s image is a masterclass in composition: the foreground trees are so perfectly positioned that it’s almost as if they’ve been planted for the photo, while the distant hill-top villa provides the all-important focal point. Composition aside, we also love the way the colours go from warm to cool as your eye moves through the image, from the sunlit flowers in the foreground to the rolling hills on the horizon.

title: Male Hummingbird Feeding on Penta by Dan Ripplinger
text:
Male Hummingbird Feeding on Penta by Dan Ripplinger
It’s hard to capture poetry in motion, but that’s exactly what the photographer has achieved here. The sharpness of the hummingbird’s face is a result of precise focusing, while the motion blur of the wings demonstrates a mastery of flash. If that wasn’t impressive enough, the subject has been isolated beautifully against the background to create an image of rare artistry.

title: Hello There by CoolbieRe
text:
Hello There by CoolbieRe
Shooting ‘contre-jour’ or into the light is a highly effective way to inject contrast into a scene. Sunrise and sunset are particularly good times of day to try this technique and a good execution will result in pleasing silhouettes like this. However, it’s the glorious, glowing, golden light that really sets this shot apart, generating a genuine feelgood factor.

title: The morning I heard a mermaid’s song by Karrah Kobus
text:
The morning I heard a mermaid’s song by Karrah Kobus
Photography is often at its most powerful when it surprises the viewer and this memorable shot certainly raised our eyebrows. The unusual composition is both dramatic and powerful, with the poles drawing the eye deeper into the scene at the same time the falling woman draws your attention across it. The starkness of the monochrome conversion enhances the mood and mystery of the scene perfectly, but ultimately pulling such an ambitious shot off comes down to impeccable timing (not to mention a willing model)!

title: Common Blue Damselfly by Keith Trueman
text:
Common Blue Damselfly by Keith Trueman
This arresting close-up clearly demonstrates the benefits of mastering the skill of focus stacking. By shooting 15 images of his carefully lit subject at subtly different focal lengths and then ‘stacking’ them in special editing software, Keith has increased his depth of field to capture a macro portrait that is as vivid as it is intimate.

title: Forever Wonder by Jack Fusco
text:
Forever Wonder by Jack Fusco
Star trails are among the most visually and technically impressive subjects to capture, typically requiring hundreds of different exposures to be combined in software following several hours of late night shooting. This is a particularly dramatic example, showing the benefits of picking a good location free from light pollution and water in the foreground to reflect the night sky. There’s even a hint of the Northern Lights for good measure!

title: Things I’ll never say by Caroline Zenker
text:
Things I’ll never say by Caroline Zenker
In a world saturated with run-of-the-mill portraiture, this intriguing image forces us to engage with its strong focus on expressive eyes and a choice of pose that hints at intrusion upon a private moment. The combination of blue and yellow hues demonstrates a clear understanding of colour theory, while the shallow depth of field puts the emphasis on the subject without rendering the setting meaningless.

title: Lake Predil, Italy by Anne Maenurm
text:
Lake Predil, Italy by Anne Maenurm
Mono milky-water images are in danger of becoming a bit cliched, but when they’re as brilliantly executed as this, they can still look fresh and original. The charcoal-sketched sky, and the shimmering detail in the foreground, combine to create an image of zen-like simplicity and serenity. In this respect, it brings to mind the landscapes of fine-art photographer Michael Kenna.

title: Horses on the run… by Páll Guðjónsson
text:
Horses on the run… by Páll Guðjónsson
This photograph was taken in Iceland near the active Eyjafjallajökull volcano. You can see the trail of ash as it is kicked up by the horses. Páll was covered in the ash after the horses had gone by!

title: Black Elder by ’yappingjak’
text:
Black Elder by ’yappingjak’
Macro images like this are deceptively difficult to take. The key here is the beautifully blurred background, which provides just enough colour and detail to add interest, but not enough to distract from the delicate intricacy of the foreground flowers.

title: KL Tower International Jump by Sally MK
text:
KL Tower International Jump by Sally MK
Taken from the KL Tower in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, this incredible shot shows a base-jumper as he has jumped from the building.

title: Road to there… by Yuriy Nezdoiminoga
text:
Road to there… by Yuriy Nezdoiminoga
This shot from Yuriy Nezdoiminoga – which was taken on the road from Tver to Kimry in Russia – really caught our eye; perfectly composed, the rainbow ends neatly at the end of the road above the white line. This almost divides the image in half, which gives more impact to the contrast of the warm colours to the right of the image, and the cooler colours to the left. Lastly, we thought this was a potent first image to choose as Photography Week’s first blog post!

title: Welcome to the blog of Photography Week, the tablet-only photography magazine, which launches in mid-September! Photography Week will be a brand new experience for photographers – it’s completely designed for tablet devices, such as the Apple iPad, from the ground up and will be packed with exciting interactive features, such as videos and image galleries. As the name suggests, it’ll come out every seven days.
text:
Welcome to the blog of Photography Week, the tablet-only photography magazine, which launches in mid-September! Photography Week will be a brand new experience for photographers – it’s completely designed for tablet devices, such as the Apple iPad, from the ground up and will be packed with exciting interactive features, such as videos and image galleries. As the name suggests, it’ll come out every seven days.
Photography Week will also include all the great features you’ve come to know and love from photography magazines, such as in-depth, practical advice for getting more out of your camera and improving your photography, detailed reviews of the latest gear and interviews with top pros from around the world. But the crucial difference with Photography Week it’s that it’s a genuinely social photography magazine for today’s photographer. We want it to be all about you and the adventures you have in photography, so we’re inviting you to get involved in every way. Not only do we want you to submit your photos for publication in our gallery, which you can do by uploading them to our Facebook page, but we’ll also hold regular photo contests and invite you to share your opinions on important issues. We want you to feel that it’s your magazine above anything else.
